facts.text: Police charge sheet dated November 13, 1949, originated the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The police charge sheet dated November 13, 1949, which originated the proceedings out of which this appeal has arisen,

facts.text: Appellant was Head Clerk of the Civil Surgeons office at Almora.

anchor.surface_text: was to the effect that the appellant, the Head Clerk of the Civil Surgeons office at Almora, misappropriated a sum

facts.text: Charge under s. 409 IPC framed: between September 26, 1947, and February 11, 1948, entrusted with Rs. 1,118-10-9, committed criminal breach of trust.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that between September 26, 1947, and February 11, 1948, he in his capacity as a public servant, having been entrusted with Rs. 1,118-10-9, committed criminal breach of trust in respect of that amount.

facts.text: Trial court acquitted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court found that on account of the improper and unsatisfactory state of affairs in which the accounts were kept in the Civil Surgeons office, ... he was acquitted.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court of Allahabad, judgment dated June 7, 1954, set aside acquittal, found guilty under s.409 IPC, sentenced to RI for 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: The State preferred an appeal to the High Court of Allahabad which by its judgment dated June 7, 1954, set aside the acquittal, found the accused guilty of an offence under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for a period of three months.

facts.text: Special leave granted by this court on July 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On an application to this court for special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, the same was granted by the order dated July 30, 1954,

facts.text: Alleged misappropriation detected some time in March 1948 when Messrs May Baker Ltd. sent reminder for unpaid bills.

anchor.surface_text: The alleged misappropriation was detected some time in March, 1948, when Messrs May Baker Ltd., sent a reminder to the Civil Surgeon, Almora, to the effect that certain bills of theirs were unpaid

facts.text: Civil Surgeon Dr. Kar enquired, appellant was on leave.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the then Civil Surgeon, Dr. Kar, enquired into the matter and found that the appellant, who was Head Clerk when he took charge, was on leave.

facts.text: Appellant sent letter Exhibit P.8 on March 5, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On sending an intimation to the appellant to submit an explanation, the latter sent a letter Exhibit P. 8 on March 5, 1948,

facts.text: Money alleged misappropriated recovered from appellant and paid in March 1948 to firms.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, according to the prosecution, the money alleged to have been misappropriated was recovered from the appellant and paid in March, 1948, to the firms whose bills were outstanding

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Almora ordered Deputy Superintendent of Police to investigate in June 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was put into the hands of the police for investigation only in June, 1949, when the Deputy Commissioner of Almora ordered the Deputy Superintendent of Police to look into the matter.

facts.text: Charge-sheet filed on November 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation, a charge-sheet was filed on November 13, 1949,

facts.text: Case submitted by S.P.O. Almora on July 10, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and the case was finally submitted by the S. P. O. Almora, on July 10, 1950,

facts.text: Case registered in court of S.D.M. Almora on August 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A case was registered in the court of the S. D. M. Almora, on August 7, 1950, against the accused under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Magistrate consigned file to record room under s.249 CrPC on November 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: As the Magistrate was of opinion that it was an indefinite thing, he consigned the file under s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code, to the record room

facts.text: District Government Counsel applied on June 4, 1951 to summon witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on June 4, 1951, the District Government Counsel applied to the S.D.M. for summoning some witnesses for examination on June 15, 1951,

facts.text: Witnesses examined starting June 16, 1951: P.W.1 Shib Lal Tewari on June 16, 1951, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings were then transferred to the Judicial Officer, Almora, who began the examination of witnesses on June 16, 1951. He examined P.W. 1 Shib Lal Tewari on June 16, 1951, P.W. 2 Bishun Singh on August 21, 1951,

facts.text: Defence of accused: undisbursed amounts kept in safe, disbursed later.

anchor.surface_text: As stated in the judgment of the High Court the defence of the accused was that the undisbursed amounts were kept in the safe in the office and were disbursed on later occasions

facts.text: High Court considered defence unacceptable, temporary misappropriation based on Ex. P.8.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court considered this defence as unacceptable and in view of the admissions contained in Ex. P. 8, they came to the conclusion that there has been a temporary misappropriation

facts.text: Important witnesses like two Civil Surgeons and auditors examined on commission by interrogatories.

anchor.surface_text: the important witnesses such as the two Civil Surgeons during whose period the alleged misappropriation took place, as well as the auditors, were examined on commission by interrogatories,

facts.text: Supreme Court finds trial vitiated due to improper examination on commission without following CrPC s.503.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

facts.text: No application by Magistrate to District Magistrate under s.503(2) CrPC for commission.

anchor.surface_text: From the review of the proceedings outlined above, it also does not appear that the trying Magistrate approached the District Magistrate with an application as contemplated in s. 503 (2), Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Appellant applied on October 16, 1951, complaining of delay since March 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On October 16, 1951, the appellant put in an application to the Magistrate stating that the case had been going on since March, 1948, and on account of the long drawn-out proceedings he was greatly harassed

facts.text: Two successive Civil Surgeons responsible for improper accounts along with accused.

anchor.surface_text: for which not only the accused but two successive Civil Surgeons were responsible, no offence has been brought home to the accused

issues.text: Whether s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code could be applied to a warrant case like this

anchor.surface_text: It has not been explained before us how s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code could be applied to a case like this, nor is it applicable to cases falling under the Chapter dealing in the warrant cases but one thing is clear that after November 30, 1950,

issues.text: Whether in a prosecution for criminal breach of trust by a Head Clerk, the trial is in strict consonance with established rules of practice where important witnesses' testimony has been obtained outside the court

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in a prosecution like this where the Head Clerk of a Civil Surgeons office is being arraigned for criminal breach of trust of sums during a particular period, and especially where the misappropriation, if any, could have been found out much earlier if the superior officers had been prompt in checking the registers and doing the duties assigned to them under the rules and regulations governing the office, it can be said that the trial is in stick consonance with established rules of practice and not in violation of the same, where the important witnesses testimony has been obtained outside the court,

issues.text: Whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court by issuing commission

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the commission was regularly set up by an order of the District Magistrate as contemplated by the above provisions, the question is as to whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court.
